title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines terms such as "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds or less, rented without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles for rental purposes. It also defines terms like "defect" and "person" according to specific sections of the United States Code. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with safety defects unless remedied prior to transaction. Exceptions apply if enforcement order is challenged in a civil action. During a rental or lease period, if a rental company receives a notification that the vehicle has a safety defect, they must immediately inform the renter or lessee and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is fixed. The rental company is considered to have received the notification five business days after it was mailed. The section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act, once any noncompliance is resolved. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Penalties for violations will be in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission Act. Nothing in this section limits the Commission's authority under other laws. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in a US district court for injunctive relief under this Act. Prior notice to the Federal Trade Commission is required before initiating such action. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in a US district court for injunctive relief under this Act. If it is not feasible for the State attorney general to provide notice, the State shall provide notice immediately upon instituting a civil action. The Federal Trade Commission may intervene in the action and be heard on all matters arising in the civil action. Nothing in this section shall prevent the State attorney general from exercising powers conferred by state laws. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in a US district court for injunctive relief under this Act. No separate suit shall be brought under this section if the same alleged violation is the subject of a pending action by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of this Act regarding the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will include details on buying practices, implications on consumer safety, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions to protect consumers. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on sales of vehicles to rental companies that may have safety defects or non-compliance issues. Rental companies must notify customers of potential defects and non-compliance during the specified period. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on sales of vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance issues, including frequency of sales, effects on consumers, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. Additionally, a follow-up report is required within 180 days of the Act's enactment regarding sales to rental companies and notification of potential defects to customers. The Administrator must submit a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year of the initial report on sales of vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance issues. The report should include analysis, recommendations, and differences in findings between the two reports. The Administrator must submit a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year on the effects of this Act on the sales of covered vehicles.
